snippet: Skype must be able to give Windows and other Microsoft products an edge for Microsoft to justify the $8.5 billion it paid, analysts said.
abstract: Analysts say Microsoft's $8.5 billion acquisition of Internet calling service Skype will ultimately be judged by whether Microsoft can weave the product into its vast portfolio; contend Skype must be able to give Windows and other Microsoft products an edge to justify the price it paid.

headline.main: $8.5 Billion Deal for Calling Service Presents a Puzzle

snippet: Is there a correlation between growing sales of Greek yogurt in the United States and the worsening Greek economic crisis?
abstract: Stuart Elliott Advertising column asks 20 questions about advertising, the media and popular culture.

headline.print_headline: Asking About Big Joe Turner, Suzy Q and Black Dahlia

snippet: Shares of the social networking company are now down 24 percent from their initial public offering earlier this month.
abstract: Shares of Facebook continue to fall sharply, even as stocks on Wall Street move solidly higher; the stock is now 24 percent below its initial offering price of $38, a sign that the bottom is yet to come as options trading begins. Graph, Photo (M)/

headline.main: Overall Market Turns Up While Facebook Slides

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: STANDARD & POOR'S CASE-SHILLER HOME PRICE INDEX

snippet: Companies are wielding patents as weapons in a blizzard of intellectual property lawsuits, which could have a devastating effect on society as a whole by short-circuiting innovation.
abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column warns that patent litigation could stifle innovation in the technology sector; says that companies are wielding patents and intellectual property as weapons and a way to stay ahead of the competition, giving a distinct advantage to larger, more financially sound businesses, and intimidating start-ups from pushing forward good ideas and improving on existing ones. Photo (M)

snippet: Can a software company build its own smartphone? We may find out soon.     This past week, Google completed its acquisition of the hardware maker Motorola Mobility for $12.5 billion, which could lead to the search giant's making its own smartphone...
abstract: Nick Bilton Disruptions column observes Facebook reportedly hopes to build and release its own smartphone by 2013; points out the motivation is clear--as a newly public company, it must find new sources of revenue, and it fears being left behind in mobile industry, one of the most promising areas for growth. Photo (M)

headline.main: Disruptions: Worried About Its Mobile Future, Facebook Looks to Build a Smartphone

snippet: The news on Tuesday that Google closed its $12.5 billion deal for Motorola is welcome for both companies, which have been waiting almost a year for the acquisition to get the final green light from regulators.      However, there might be a third ...
abstract: Bits blog; Microsoft's Windows Phone software may gain traction among phone makers if they become wary of Android because Google now owns competing phone maker Motorola Mobility. (M)

snippet: Cisco announced on Thursday that it would be discontinuing its Cius tablet. Cisco cited the failure of the product on a ''market transition,'' which is a good way to describe the reality: people didn't buy it.     The reason is clear from Cisco's ...
abstract: Bits blog; Cisco will discontinue its Cius tablet due to poor sales. (M)5

headline.main: Cisco Brings End To Its Cius Tablet
